HTML

Give your page structure and meaning with HTML!

HTML

HTML is the language that describes the structure and semantic content of a document on the web; it consists of:

  • content (just plain text) üìñ
  • and elements (tags) that give structure to the text üî®

HTML is for content and structure

Hyper-Text Markup Language.

Hyper-Text ‚ÜíBecause it allows you to link to other documents on the web! üåé

What about the markup part? ‚Üí

  • markup is a method of annotating text‚Ä¶
    • markup itself is syntactically distinguishable from content
    • markup is applied to text by using tags
  • HTML is generally not considered a language in the programming language sense

Elements and Tags

An element a single part of an HTML document; it encompasses both structure and (optionally) content: a paragraph, navigation, etc.

  • an element is made up of tags and, optionally, text: <p>Some Content</p>
  • tags are used to mark the start and end of an HTML element: <p> ... </p>
  • an opening tag is an element‚Äôs name surrounded by angle brackets: <p>
  • an closing tag is an element‚Äôs name prefixed with a forward slash and surrounded by angle brackets: </p>

Tags Continued

There are a few ways that tags and content can be combined to create elements. ‚Üí

  • an open and close tag surrounding content: <h1>So Flawless</h1>
  • an open and close tag without content: <script src="iamhackr.js"><script>
  • only an open tag <img src="puppies.png">

Attributes

An opening tag can contain attributes

  • an attribute is part of a tag that provides additional information about an element
  • it‚Äôs composed of a name/value pair joined by an equal sign
  • it‚Äôs is placed after the name of the element in a tag, but before the last angle bracket: <img src="puppies.png">
  • the value doesn‚Äôt have to be quoted, but it‚Äôs good practice to do so‚Ä¶ to avoid issues like this:<input type=text value=what is this>

A Quick Diagram

Name the parts of this markup ‚Üí

<a href="http://we.love.pizza>pizza!</a>

                element
                    |
     +--------------+---------------------+
     |                                    | 
    <a href="http://we.love.pizza">pizza!</a>
     |      |                             |
     |      attribute                     |
start tag                            end tag

Special Characters

Some Characters Have Meaning in HTML

(for example: <, >, &)

If you need these characters in your content, Use an HTML entity, a sequence of characters that represents these special characters

  • HTML entities start with &, followed by a name, and end with ;
  • for example, &lt; is < and &amp; is an &
  • a list of HTML entities

Some Commonly Used HTML Entities:

&amp; ... ampersand (&)
&nbsp; ... non breaking space ( )
&lt; ... less than (<)
&gt; ... greater than (>)
&quot; ... double quotes (")
&apos; ... single quote (')

HTML Specifications

Two groups, WHATWG and W3C, work together to specify HTML üñãÔ∏è

  • Web Hypertext Application Technology Working Group has a living HTML standard
    • continuously evolving standard
    • no version numbers
    • community driven
  • World Wide Web Consortium) is basing the most recent versions of HTML on WHATWG‚Äôs living standard
    • it snapshots versions
    • the latest version is HTML5
    • version releases are a bit slower than WHATWG‚Äôs

HTML5, doctype

HTML5 is the most current version of HTML. It defines a bunch of things:

  • actual markup (like we‚Äôve seen already) ‚úîÔ∏è
  • scripting APIs (through JavaScript) ‚úîÔ∏è

To indicate that your page uses HTML5, use the following doctype declaration at the top of your page:

<!doctype html>

This doctype will let browsers know how to render your page.

Dealing with Bad Markup

Browsers are pretty forgiving when it comes to bad markup: üòÖ

No tags surrounding me!

html, head, and body tags are inserted

<html>
<body>
		Where's my close body?
</html>

body is automatically closed

And Now, Some Elements

Finally‚Ä¶ a quick tour of some elements you‚Äôll be using

(check out mdn‚Äôs html elements reference for more detail!

Root, Meta Data and Content Elements

<!doctype html>: informs the browser to use the appropriate rendering mode for this version of html

<html></html>: the root or top-level element of a document.

<head></head>: contains meta data about the document, like which css file(s) to use (link), the title of the document (shown in the tab), etc.

<body></body>: the content of the document; only one body per document

That Meta Data‚Ä¶

Within the Head Element

<link href=‚Äùname-of-file.css‚Äù rel=‚Äùstylesheet‚Äù>: bring in a stylesheet

<title></title>: title of the page

Headers, Footers and Navigation

<header></header>: represents introductory content such as navigation, logo, search form etc.

<footer></footer>: typically contains content such as copyright information, author, etc.

<h1></h1> (through <h6>): section headers with 1 being the highest and 6 being the lowest

<nav></nav>: describes a part of the page that provides navigation (there can be more than one nav element)

Breaking Up Your Actual Content

<article></article>: self-contained composition, possibly independently distributable (blog or forum post, magazine article, a user‚Äôs comment, etc.)

<section></section>: generic section of your page (thematic grouping of content, usually with heading), like chapters in a book, broad sections of page (overview, news, contact)

<img src=‚Äù/path/to/image.jpg‚Äù alt=‚Äùdescribes image‚Äù>: an image, no closing tag

<br>: line break (no closing tag)

<hr>: horizontal line (no closing tag)

Blocks

For organizing blocks / sections of content within body‚Ä¶

<p></p>: pargraph

<blockquote></blockquote>: extended quotation

<ul></ul>, <ol></ol> and nested <li></li>: unordered and ordered list with nested list items

<div></div>: generic block element

<table></table> (along with thead, tbody, tr, td): tabular data

Inline

For annotating a word or line‚Ä¶

<a href=‚Äù/path/to/page.html‚Äù></a>: link to another page or section within this page

<strong></strong>: element has strong importance / urgency within context of document

<span></span>: generic inline element
